In 1939, the Bureau initiated a confidential list of individuals who would be detained in the event of war with Axis powers. The majority of the listed individuals were Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built upon an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast. However, the list also included many German and Italian nationals. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, secured permission from Hoover to begin detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, as the attack on Pearl Harbor was still unfolding. Following the attack, mass arrests and home searches (in most cases conducted without warrants) commenced, and over the next few weeks, more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. On February 19, 1942, President Franklin Roosevelt issued Executive Order 9066, authorizing the removal of Japanese Americans from the West Coast. Despite this, FBI Director Hoover expressed opposition to the policy.

The body's response to an antigen is influenced by several factors, including age, antigen type, maternal influences, and the location where the antigen is presented. At birth, newborns are in a state of physiological immunodeficiency due to the suppression of both their innate and adaptive immune responses. While their immune system responds well to protein antigens, it has limited effectiveness against glycoproteins and polysaccharides. This is why many infections acquired by newborns are caused by low-virulence microorganisms like Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas. In newborns, the ability to activate the complement system and opsonic activity is significantly limited. For instance, the average level of C3 in a newborn is about 65% of that found in an adult. Furthermore, phagocytic activity is impaired in newborns due to lower opsonic activity and diminished up-regulation of integrin and selectin receptors, which hinders neutrophils' ability to interact with adhesion molecules in the endothelium.

Following India's independence, the Chief Commissioner's Province of Himachal Pradesh was established on April 15, 1948, as a result of the unification of 28 smaller princely states, including the Simla Hills States and four Punjab southern hill states. This integration was facilitated by the Himachal Pradesh (Administration) Order, 1948, which fell under Sections 3 and 4 of the Extra-Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947 (later renamed as the Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1947). The State of Bilaspur was subsequently merged with Himachal Pradesh on April 1, 1954, through the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur (New State) Act, 1954. With the implementation of the Constitution of India on January 26, 1950, Himachal Pradesh was reclassified as a part C state.

The term "Bleacher Bums" refers to a group of rowdy fans who occupy the bleacher section at Wrigley Field, frequently engaging in loud and boisterous behavior throughout the day. The origin of the name "Bleacher Bums" stems from the perception that these fans were unemployed, as they attended almost every game, which were typically daytime events. Interestingly, many of these Bleacher Bums are actually students from local Chicago-area universities, including DePaul, Loyola, Northwestern, and Illinois-Chicago. A popular Broadway play, starring Joe Mantegna, Dennis Farina, Dennis Franz, and James Belushi, was inspired by the antics of these eccentric fans and ran for several years.

At approximately 1:17 pm PDT (20:17 UTC), the torch was ignited at AT&T Park's outdoor location, held briefly by American and Chinese Olympic officials. However, the relay soon descended into chaos when the first runner vanished into a waterfront pier warehouse for about 30 minutes. The situation was further complicated by clashes between thousands of pro-China protesters, many of whom claimed to have been transported by the Chinese Consulate and other pro-China groups, and advocates for Tibet and Darfur. The non-Chinese demonstrators were reportedly overwhelmed and pursued by angry crowds. By 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch reappeared around 3 km (1.9 mi) away from the stadium along Van Ness Avenue, a busy street that was not part of the original route plan. Television broadcasts captured images of the flame.

A standard adult football match is divided into two equal periods, each lasting 45 minutes, referred to as halves. The clock runs continuously throughout each half, uninterrupted by stoppages in play. A 15-minute break, known as halftime, separates the two halves. The match concludes at full-time. The referee serves as the official timekeeper, allocating additional time for substitutions, player injuries, and other stoppages. This additional time is often referred to as stoppage time, injury time, or loss time, and is at the referee's discretion. The referee is responsible for signaling the end of the match, although in matches with a fourth official, the referee will indicate the intended stoppage time towards the end of the half, and the fourth official will inform the players and spectators through a visual display.

The identification of an infectious agent is typically only pursued when it can lead to effective treatment, prevention, or a deeper understanding of the disease's progression before therapeutic or preventative measures are developed. For instance, in the early 1980s, when AZT was not yet available to treat AIDS, researchers closely monitored the blood compositions of patients to track the disease's progression, despite not being able to offer additional treatment options. These studies allowed for the advancement of theories on the virus's transmission routes, particularly in specific communities. By understanding how the disease was transmitted, resources could be targeted to high-risk areas, thereby reducing the number of new infections. The specific identification of HIV through serological, genotypic, or molecular methods also enabled researchers to develop hypotheses about the virus's temporal and geographical origins, ultimately informing targeted prevention strategies.

Since gaining independence, Estonia has positioned itself as a bridge between Eastern and Western cultures, actively pursuing economic reforms and integration with the West. Estonia's market-oriented reforms have positioned it among the leading economies in the former COMECON region. In 1994, inspired by Milton Friedman's economic theories, Estonia became one of the first countries to adopt a flat tax system, with a uniform rate of 26% applied to all personal income. Subsequently, the personal income tax rate was reduced to 24% in January 2005, followed by another decrease to 23% in January 2006. By January 2008, the rate was further lowered to 21%. The Estonian government finalized the design of the country's euro coins in late 2004 and adopted the euro as its official currency on January 1, 2011, following a slight delay due to persistent inflationary pressures. Additionally, Estonia levies a Land Value Tax, which is utilized to fund local municipalities. Although it is a state-level tax, the entire revenue generated is allocated to support local councils, with the rate being set by the government.

The island of Saint Helena, spanning 122 km2 (47 sq mi), is primarily characterized by rugged terrain of volcanic origin, with the last volcanic activity dating back around 7 million years. The coastal regions, covered in volcanic rock, exhibit warmer and drier conditions compared to the central areas. The highest point, Diana's Peak, stands at 818 m (2,684 ft), and was declared the island's first national park in 1996. New Zealand flax dominates much of the island, a remnant of former industry, although some original trees remain, supplemented by plantations, including the Millennium Forest project, established in 2002 to replant a portion of the lost Great Wood, now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. Upon its discovery, the island was teeming with unique indigenous vegetation, including an extraordinary cabbage tree species. It is believed that the island's interior was once a dense tropical forest, while the coastal areas were likely similarly dense, although the exact extent of this is still unknown.

In the mid-1980s, established bands regained their momentum. After an eight-year hiatus, Deep Purple reunited with their classic Machine Head lineup to release Perfect Strangers in 1984, which achieved impressive chart success, reaching number five in the UK and top five in five other countries, while being certified platinum in the US. Van Halen, following somewhat slower sales with their fourth album, Fair Warning, bounced back with the Top 3 album Diver Down in 1982, before reaching their commercial peak with 1984. This album climbed to number two on the Billboard album chart, featuring the hit single "Jump", which reached number one on the singles chart and stayed there for several weeks. Meanwhile, Heart, which had struggled during the early 1980s, made a comeback with their eponymous ninth studio album, which debuted at number one and included four Top 10 singles, including their first number one hit.

In the United States, a predominantly two-party system has emerged, with the Republican Party representing conservative ideologies and the Democratic Party embodying liberal views. This dichotomy has been a consistent feature of American politics, dating back to the early days of Federalist and Republican parties. The Republican Party dominated initially, but later split into National Republicans and Democratic Republicans, ultimately giving rise to the Whig and Democratic parties. The Whigs, however, were short-lived, disintegrating over the slavery issue, with some members joining the newly formed Republican Party, while others remained within the Democratic Party. Although third parties, such as the Libertarian Party, typically receive limited support and rarely win elections, there have been instances where they have drawn votes away from major parties, as seen in the cases of Theodore Roosevelt in 1912 and George Wallace in 1968.

Notre Dame underwent significant changes to its conference affiliations in 2013, affecting most sports apart from football and fencing, which will undergo a change in 2014. The university left the Big East and joined the ACC, maintaining its football independence while committing to play five games per season against ACC opponents. The shift was prompted by the Big East's prolonged instability. In ice hockey, Notre Dame was compelled to find a new conference home following the Big Ten's decision to add the sport in 2013-14, which led to the Central Collegiate Hockey Association's dissolution after the 2012-13 season. The university subsequently moved its hockey team to Hockey East. After joining the ACC, the conference announced its intention to add fencing as a sponsored sport, effective from the 2014-15 school year. Despite various theories surrounding the origins of the athletics moniker, it is known that the Fighting Irish name was adopted.

Among the 80 torch-bearers in London, Sir Steve Redgrave, who kick-started the relay, revealed to the media that he had received emails urging him to boycott the event, and acknowledged that he could understand why some would want to make an issue out of it. Notably, Francesca Martinez and Richard Vaughan declined to carry the torch, whereas Konnie Huq chose to proceed with the relay while also voicing her concerns about China. Meanwhile, pro-Tibetan Member of Parliament Norman Baker appealed to all bearers to reconsider their involvement. Amidst the intense pressure from both sides, Prime Minister Gordon Brown welcomed the torch outside 10 Downing Street, but refrained from touching or holding it. The London leg of the relay was accompanied by a "mobile protective ring," as described by the BBC. The event was marred by protests from the outset, resulting in at least thirty-five arrests. During the relay, a demonstrator attempted to snatch the torch from Konnie Huq in a brief scuffle, and a fire extinguisher was also set off near the torch. The Chinese ambassador carried the torch through London's Chinatown afterwards.

Jerusalem holds immense spiritual significance for Jews, Muslims, and Christians, as it is the cradle of sites deeply revered in their respective faiths. The Old City, comprising the Western Wall and the Temple Mount, the Al-Aqsa Mosque, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, is a testament to this sacred importance. In Israel, other notable religious sites include Nazareth, revered in Christianity as the site of the Annunciation of Mary; Tiberias and Safed, two of the Four Holy Cities in Judaism; the White Mosque in Ramla, a shrine of profound significance in Islam, commemorating the prophet Saleh; and the Church of Saint George in Lod, a sacred location shared by Christianity and Islam, where Saint George or Al Khidr is believed to be buried. Furthermore, the West Bank is home to a multitude of other revered landmarks, including Joseph's Tomb in Nablus, the birthplace of Jesus, and Rachel's Tomb in Bethlehem, among others.

In many cases, non-alphanumeric characters on typewriters were positioned in accordance with their shifted positions on mechanical typewriters, a crucial detail that sets them apart from their electric counterparts. This convention was influenced by the Remington No. 2, the first typewriter featuring a shift key, which was introduced in 1878. Early mechanical typewriters, including the Remington No. 2, did not include the digits 0 and 1, instead using the capital letter "O" and lowercase letter "L" to represent these numbers. However, once 0 and 1 became more common, the 1! and 0) pairs became standard. As a result, in ASCII, the characters!"#$% were placed in the second column, rows 1-5, corresponding to the digits 1-5 in the adjacent column. Notably, the parentheses could not be aligned with the characters 9 and 0 due to the space character occupying the position corresponding to 0. To address this, the underscore character was removed from the equation.

The adolescent stage is characterized by a dramatic shift in a young person's role within their family. Initially, children assert themselves strongly, but they lack significant influence over family decisions until early adolescence, when they begin to be regarded by their parents as equals. During this period, adolescents must navigate the delicate balance of increasing independence while maintaining a close, caring relationship with their parents. The onset of puberty often leads to a surge in parent-adolescent conflict and a less cohesive family bond. Disagreements frequently revolve around minor issues of control, such as curfew, acceptable attire, and the adolescent's right to privacy, which may have previously been seen as the exclusive domain of parents. The growing influence of friends on each other also contributes to increased disagreements, as adolescents are exposed to new values and perspectives that may clash with those of their parents. Furthermore, social media has become a significant factor in adolescent and parent disagreements, as parents must now contend with the potential threats and consequences of their child's online activities.

Microbiological culture is a fundamental diagnostic tool for identifying infectious diseases. In this process, a growth medium is provided specifically for a particular microorganism. A sample is then taken from potentially infected tissue or fluid and tested for the presence of an infectious agent that can thrive in that medium. Most pathogenic bacteria can be easily cultivated on nutrient agar, a type of solid medium that supplies essential carbohydrates and proteins for bacterial growth, as well as abundant water. A single bacterium will develop into a visible mound on the plate's surface, referred to as a colony, which may be distinct from other colonies or merge into a uniform "lawn." The size, color, shape, and appearance of a colony are characteristic of the bacterial species, its specific genetic makeup (strain), and the environmental conditions that support its growth. Other additives may be included on the plate to facilitate identification. Plates can also contain substances that enable the growth of specific bacteria.

Around 20% of Eton's student body benefits from financial assistance, courtesy of a variety of bursaries and scholarships. In a recent statement, former Head Master Tony Little revealed that Eton is actively working to make the school accessible to any boy, regardless of his family's income. In 2011, he reported that approximately 250 students received substantial financial support from the institution. By early 2014, this number had increased to 263 pupils, who received school fee assistance equivalent to 60% of the total cost, while an additional 63 students attended the school without incurring any tuition fees. Little aimed to achieve a short-term goal of providing bursaries to around 320 students annually, with 70 pupils receiving their education entirely free of charge. He ultimately intends to see a significant expansion of the school's financial aid programs.

Prior to the formation of Queen, Brian May and Roger Taylor collaborated in the band Smile. During this period, Freddie Mercury, then known as Farrokh "Freddie" Bulsara, became a fan and encouraged the duo to explore innovative stage and recording techniques. Mercury eventually joined Smile in 1970, proposed the name "Queen" for their new band, and adopted his iconic stage name. John Deacon was recruited before the recording of their debut album, titled Queen, in 1973. Queen initially gained chart success in the UK with their second album, Queen II, in 1974. However, it was the release of Sheer Heart Attack later that year and A Night at the Opera in 1975 that propelled them to international stardom. The latter album featured the groundbreaking hit "Bohemian Rhapsody," which held the number one spot in the UK for nine consecutive weeks and popularized the concept of music videos. Their 1977 album, News of the World, included the enduring anthems "We Will Rock You" and "We Are the Champions," which have since become synonymous with sporting events.

On March 13, the port city of Clydebank near Glasgow, Scotland, was subjected to a bombing raid, leaving only seven of its 12,000 houses unscathed. This devastating attack was not an isolated incident, as numerous other British ports came under attack that month. Plymouth, for instance, was hit five times, while Belfast, Hull, and Cardiff were also targeted. The city of Cardiff suffered three consecutive nights of bombing, with Portsmouth's central area being particularly ravaged by five raids. The civilian housing crisis was dire, with an average of 40,000 people being forced to flee their homes each week by September 1940. In March 1941, two major raids on Plymouth and London displaced a staggering 148,000 people. Despite the widespread destruction, British ports continued to play a crucial role in supporting the war effort, with supplies from North America still flowing through them and the Royal Navy maintaining its operations in Plymouth, Southampton, and Portsmouth. Plymouth, situated on the vulnerable south coast and near German air bases, bore the brunt of the attacks. On the night of March 10-11, a massive force of 240 bombers dropped 193 tons of high explosives and 46,000 incendiary devices, resulting in significant damage to residential areas and commercial districts.

The origins of collegiate a cappella are unclear, although the Rensselyrics of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, established in 1873, is likely the oldest known collegiate a cappella group. However, the longest continuously performing group is probably The Whiffenpoofs of Yale University, which was founded in 1909 and boasted Cole Porter as a former member. Collegiate a cappella groups experienced significant growth throughout the 20th century. Notable historical groups that emerged during this time include the Tigertones at Princeton University (1946), The Colgate 13 at Colgate University (1942), the Aires at Dartmouth College (1946), Cayuga's Waiters at Cornell University (1949), The Hangovers at Cornell University (1968), the Maine Steiners at the University of Maine (1958), the Kingsmen at Columbia University (1949), the Jabberwocks at Brown University (1949), and the YellowJackets at the University of Rochester (1956). The all-women a cappella groups followed shortly, often as a parody of the men's groups: the Smiffenpoofs at Smith College (1936), The Shwiffs at Connecticut College (1930s), and other notable groups such as The Amherst College Women's Chorus (1950s) and The University of Pennsylvania's Off the Beat (1980s).

Adolescents' peer groups provide a platform for them to explore their emotions, identity, and social skills. These groups offer opportunities for developing essential social skills, such as empathy, sharing, and leadership. Individuals are drawn to peer groups that mirror their own characteristics, allowing them to feel more comfortable in their own skin. By engaging with their peers, adolescents internalize group norms and values, which in turn shape their self-concept. Through communication with their peers, they develop new skills, reflect on their own opinions and values, and feel more confident in expressing emotions and concerns without fear of rejection or judgment. Peer groups can have a significant impact on an individual's life, influencing their academic motivation and performance. While peers can facilitate social development, they can also hinder it by promoting negative behaviors such as drug use, vandalism, and stealing through peer pressure. Research has shown that susceptibility to peer pressure peaks around age 14 and decreases thereafter. Moreover, the influence of peers on adolescents is a complex phenomenon that warrants further exploration.

Following a period of internal turmoil, the Liberal Party was plagued by a leadership contest between John Howard, the former Treasurer, and Andrew Peacock, the former Foreign Minister. Meanwhile, the Australian economy was grappling with the early 1990s recession, characterized by soaring unemployment rates of 11.4% in 1992. In November 1991, under the leadership of Dr. John Hewson, the opposition launched the comprehensive Fightback! policy document, a 650-page manifesto outlining a radical agenda of economic liberalization. This ambitious plan included the introduction of a Goods and Services Tax, significant reforms to Medicare, a nine-month limit on unemployment benefits, changes to industrial relations, a $13 billion tax cut for middle and upper-income earners, and $10 billion in government spending reductions. The document also proposed the abolition of state payroll taxes, the privatization of numerous government-owned enterprises, and a distinct shift away from the Keynesian economic conservatism that had defined previous Liberal and National Coalition governments, signaling a significant departure from the party's traditional stance.

Scholars of law have scrutinized the depiction of legal issues in Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird, particularly in scenes outside the courtroom. As Claudia Durst Johnson observes, legal scholars have generated a substantial body of critical analysis in law journals, surpassing the literary scholars' output in literary journals. The novel's opening quote from Charles Lamb, a 19th-century essayist, resonates with the theme: "Lawyers, I suppose, were children once." Johnson notes that even in the childhood world of Scout and Jem, compromises and treaties are forged through informal agreements, while legal discussions unfold, such as Atticus and his children debating whether Bob Ewell's hunting and trapping out of season are justifiable. Furthermore, symbolic courtrooms are set up in various social contexts, where norms are challenged. For instance, Mr. Dolphus Raymond has been ostracized by society for his unconventional relationship with a black woman and their interracial children, highlighting the societal codes that are broken and the moral dilemmas that arise from them.

Queen's A Night at the Opera, named after the classic Marx Brothers film, was released in late 1975, boasting the distinction of being the most costly album production at the time. Like its precursor, this album showcases the band's eclectic musical range and innovative use of stereo sound. One notable track is the eight-minute epic "The Prophet's Song", which features a captivating canon section, crafted by layering simple phrases to create a rich, choral atmosphere. The poignant ballad "Love of My Life", penned by Freddie Mercury, incorporates a harp and lush, overdubbed vocal harmonies. The album received widespread acclaim in the UK, achieving triple platinum status in the US, and in 2004, it ranked 13th in a Channel 4 poll as one of the greatest albums of all time. It has also consistently ranked high in international polls, earning the 19th spot in a Guinness poll and 28th in an ABC poll, with the Australian public voting it one of the greatest albums of all time.

While the doctrine of Mary's Immaculate Conception emerged later among Latin and Frankish theologians, it gained prominence among Byzantine scholars who drew inspiration from Gregory Nazianzen's Mariology in the Medieval East. Although hymn writers and scholars, such as Emperor Justinian I, frequently referred to Mary as "prepurified" in their poetic and creedal statements, it was Sophronius of Jerusalem who provided the initial insight into Nazianzen's meaning. In his writings, Sophronius explained that Mary was already immaculate at the Annunciation, when she was "purified," and even went so far as to note that John the Baptist was holier than any other human being born of woman, since Mary's exceptional holiness signified that she was even holier than John after his sanctification in the womb. Sophronius' teachings were later expanded upon and incorporated by St. John Damascene. In addition to numerous passages praising the Theotokos for her purification at the Annunciation, John bestowed upon her the unique honor of "purifying the waters of baptism by touching them."

Along the torch relay route, a series of protests unfolded, with members of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China, including renowned pro-democracy activist Szeto Wah, brandishing inflatable Olympic flames to symbolize democracy. They demanded accountability for the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989 and the implementation of democratic reforms in Hong Kong. Notably, political activist and Legislative Council member Leung Kwok-hung, also known as "Longhair," joined the protest, expressing pride in Hong Kong's courageous individuals who dare to speak out. However, pro-democracy activists were met with a counter-crowd of torch supporters hurling insults such as "running dog," "traitor," "get out!," and "I love the Communist Party." Meanwhile, around 10 members of the Civil Human Rights Front carried orange banners calling for human rights improvements and universal suffrage. Onlookers attempted to cover the banners with a large Chinese national flag, shouting "Aren't you Chinese?" in Mandarin. One woman, in particular, stood out as she attempted to resist the attempts to silence her and the other protesters.

Zhejiang Province's primary industrial sectors include electromechanical manufacturing, textiles, chemicals, food processing, and construction materials. The province has adopted a distinct development strategy, known as the "Zhejiang model," which focuses on fostering entrepreneurship, small business growth, and market responsiveness. This approach is characterized by significant public investments in infrastructure and a focus on producing low-cost goods in bulk for both domestic consumption and export. As a result, Zhejiang has emerged as one of China's most affluent provinces, with the "Zhejiang spirit" earning a reputation as a benchmark for success. Nevertheless, some economists are now concerned that this model may not be sustainable in the long term, as it is inefficient and places excessive demands on natural resources and public utilities. Moreover, the countless small businesses in Zhejiang producing low-cost goods may struggle to transition to more complex or technologically advanced industries, potentially limiting the province's future growth prospects.

In December, Beyoncé joined forces with other celebrities to create a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan initiative launched by 950 US mayors to persuade the federal government to reassess its gun control policies in the wake of the Sandy Hook Elementary School tragedy. Prior to this, Beyoncé served as an ambassador for the 2012 World Humanitarian Day campaign, contributing her song "I Was Here" and its music video, filmed at the UN headquarters, to the cause. In 2013, it was announced that she would collaborate with Salma Hayek and Frida Giannini on Gucci's "Chime for Change" campaign, which aimed to promote female empowerment. The campaign, which premiered on February 28, featured Beyoncé's new music, and a concert event was held in London on June 1, 2013, featuring performances by Ellie Goulding, Florence and the Machine, and Rita Ora. Ahead of the concert, Beyoncé appeared in a campaign video released on May 15, 2013, where she and other prominent figures emphasized the importance of the initiative.

Despite offering a range of academic disciplines, including calligraphic arts, oral traditions, and intellectual pursuits, Ottoman madaris primarily functioned as institutions dedicated to spiritual education in the Islamic tradition. As İnalcık notes, the ultimate goal of knowledge, particularly spiritual sciences, is to gain a deeper understanding of God. In the Ottoman madrasa, the significance and importance of each subject were largely determined by its relevance to Islam. For instance, sciences like astrology were deemed undesirable, while those that supported religious beliefs were valued. Mathematics and logic, although part of the curriculum, were subordinated to religious principles. Interestingly, even mathematical teachings were underpinned by a religious motivation, as the Ulema believed that these subjects helped develop critical thinking and ultimately revealed divine truths. Similarly, philosophy was only permitted within the context of Islamic thought, with İnalcık noting that it was seen as a means to further explore and understand divine mysteries.

Galicia's earliest human inhabitants date back to the Middle Paleolithic era, while its name originates from the Gallaeci, a Celtic tribe that inhabited the region north of the Douro river during the last millennium before Christ. The Gallaeci's territory roughly corresponded to the Iron Age Castro culture. Following the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, Galicia became part of the Roman Empire, eventually being transformed into a Roman province in the 3rd century AD. The Germanic Suebi established a kingdom in Braga, Portugal, in 410, which was later incorporated into the Visigoth kingdom in 585. In 711, the Arabs invaded the Iberian Peninsula, capturing the Visigoth kingdom. However, Galicia was eventually incorporated into the Christian kingdom of Asturias in 740. Throughout the Middle Ages, Galicia's monarchy experienced periods of self-governance, with its own kings ruling on occasion, but often being aligned with the kingdom of Asturias.

Upon its release, Twilight Princess was widely acclaimed by critics, with many regarding it as the best Zelda game ever made. Pundits from publications like 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, IGN, and The Washington Post shared this sentiment. Game Informer lauded the game as "a creative masterpiece rivaling the best Hollywood has to offer," while GamesRadar bestowed upon it "the absolute highest recommendation." Cubed3 proclaimed Twilight Princess "the single greatest videogame experience" ever had. The game's visual style and animation received widespread praise, despite being designed for the GameCube, which was technically inferior to the next-generation consoles. Although IGN and GameSpy noted the presence of blurry textures and low-resolution characters, Computer and Video Games felt that the game's atmosphere surpassed that of any previous Zelda game, with PALGN deeming Hyrule the best version ever created. The publication also praised the game's cinematics, stating that "the cutscenes are the best in the series."

The islands of Great Britain and Ireland have diverse topography, with the majority of the terrain lying at relatively low elevations. The lowest point is found in Cambridgeshire, England, with an altitude of -2.75 meters (-9.02 feet). In contrast, the Scottish Highlands in northern Great Britain are characterized by rugged mountains, with Ben Nevis being the highest peak at 1,343 meters (4,406 feet). Other mountainous regions can be found in Wales and parts of Ireland, although only seven peaks exceed 1,000 meters (3,281 feet) in height. The islands' lakes are generally modest in size, with the exception of Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland, which covers an area of 150 square miles (390 km2). Notably, Loch Lomond in Scotland is the largest freshwater body in Great Britain by area, measuring 27.5 square miles (71 km2), while Loch Ness is the largest by volume. Additionally, Loch Morar is the deepest freshwater body in the British Isles, with a maximum depth of 310 meters (1,017 feet).

The aftermath of World War II left a lasting impact on Britain and the empire, as well as the global landscape. The war-ravaged continent of Europe, once a dominant world power, was now a battleground for the armies of the United States and the Soviet Union, who had emerged as global heavyweights. Britain, meanwhile, was on the brink of bankruptcy, only saved by a $US 4.33 billion loan from the United States in 1946, the final installment of which wasn't paid off until 2006. Amidst this turmoil, anti-colonial movements were gaining momentum in European colonies, further complicating the situation. The escalating Cold War rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union added to the complexity, as both nations ostensibly opposed colonialism. However, in reality, the US prioritized anti-communism over anti-imperialism, leading to its support for the continued existence of the British Empire as a means of containing Communist expansion.

According to Homer, the Hellenes were a relatively small tribe inhabiting Thessalic Phthia, with their warriors led by the legendary Achilleus. The Parian Chronicle records that Phthia was the ancestral homeland of the Hellenes, and that this name was bestowed upon those previously known as the Greeks (Γραικοί). In Greek mythology, Hellen, the patriarch of the Hellenes, was the son of Pyrrha and Deucalion, who reigned over Phthia following the great deluge, and were the sole survivors. It appears that this myth was concocted when the Greek tribes began to disperse across various regions of Greece, serving as a testament to their shared origins. Aristotle, in turn, refers to ancient Hellas as an entity that existed prior to the separation of the Greek tribes.

Despite the uncertainty, the Luftwaffe posed a significant threat. The German occupation of Western Europe heightened concerns about intensified submarine and air raids on Britain's maritime connections, which would have far-reaching implications for the war's trajectory if successful. Liverpool, a crucial destination for convoys from North America, served as a vital hub for supplies and resources. The extensive rail network then dispersed these goods throughout the country. The Luftwaffe's attacks on Liverpool during the Blitz were effective. A total of 39,126 long tons of shipping were sunk, with another 111,601 long tons damaged. Minister of Home Security Herbert Morrison was also troubled by the decline in morale, citing civilians' defeatist sentiments. Additionally, reports suggest that half of the port's 144 berths were rendered inoperable, and cargo unloading capacity was reduced by 75%. The attacks blocked roads and railways, leaving ships stranded in harbour. On May 8, 1941, 57 ships were destroyed, exacerbating the city's distress.

During King George V's reign, a significant renovation took place in 1913, when Sir Aston Webb reimagined the East Front, originally designed by Blore in 1850, to resemble Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. The newly refaced principal façade, crafted from Portland stone, served as a striking backdrop for the Victoria Memorial, a large statue of Queen Victoria, situated outside the main gates. Notably, George V's personality differed from his father's; he prioritized official duties and entertaining over extravagant parties. To that end, he organized a series of command performances, featuring notable jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919), Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), marking the first jazz performance for a head of state. This endeavor earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival, recognizing its significant contribution to the development of jazz music in the United Kingdom.

The brief respite in European conflicts enabled Napoleon to redirect his attention to France's overseas territories. Following the Revolutionary Wars, Saint-Domingue had achieved a significant degree of autonomy, with Toussaint Louverture assuming the role of de facto leader by 1801. Seizing the opportunity presented by the Treaty of Amiens, Napoleon aimed to regain control of the formerly prosperous colony. During the Revolution, the National Convention had voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. However, under the terms of the Treaty of Amiens, Napoleon agreed to placate British demands by refraining from abolishing slavery in colonies where the 1794 decree had not been implemented. This led to the passage of the Law of 20 May, which restored the slave trade to Caribbean colonies, rather than slavery itself. In response, Napoleon dispatched an expedition under General Leclerc to tackle the situation.

The concept of Mary's sinlessness and exemption from any taint since the moment of her creation was a widely accepted doctrine among Byzantine Greek theologians. Specifically, St. Gregory Nazianzen's explanation of Jesus' and Mary's "purification" at the circumcision (Luke 2:22) led him to redefine the term "purification" in Christology and Mariology. According to St. Gregory, "purification" refers to a sinless nature that was perfected in glory at a moment of divine favor (e.g., Jesus' Baptism). Nazianzen designated Mary as "prepurified" (prokathartheisa), suggesting that both Jesus and Mary shared equally holy human natures, which were consequently purified through this divine act. St. Gregory likely employed this doctrine to resolve the paradox of the Purification of Jesus and Mary in the Temple. His ideas surrounding Mary's purification may have been tied to the growing veneration of the Mother of God in and around Constantinople, which coincided with the celebration of Christmas. Nazianzen's title of Mary as "prepurified" at the Annunciation was later adopted by others.

Until 1841, the state's close ties with the United States maintained a sense of tranquility, distinct from the rest of the country. However, by 1843, the government anticipated the possibility of war and took proactive measures to fortify its defenses along the Texas border. This included arming the military, optimizing efficiency at presidios, and organizing the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border, comprising light cavalry, four squads of brigades, and a small contingent of 14 men and 42 officials, all at a cost of 160,603 pesos annually. Meanwhile, private citizens attempted to intercept commercial caravans carrying supplies from the United States, but due to their remote location from central Mexico's major suppliers, they were allowed to pass in March 1844. As war seemed increasingly likely, the state legislature issued a decree on July 11, 1846, enlisting 6,000 men for military service.

In the spring of 1800, Napoleon's forces traversed the treacherous Swiss Alps, intent on catching the Austrian armies off guard in Italy. As they entered the Italian plains, they faced minimal resistance, allowing them to establish a strong foothold. Meanwhile, the Austrians were preoccupied with a force besieging Genoa, while a separate army, led by André Masséna, offered fierce resistance, buying time for the northern French army to regroup. Following a few days of searching for each other, the two armies clashed at the Battle of Marengo on June 14. Despite being outnumbered, with approximately 24,000 French troops compared to the Austrians' 30,000, Napoleon's forces initially fared poorly, with the Austrians launching a successful initial attack that drove them back. In Homer's Iliad, the terms Danaans and Argives are employed to refer to the Greek forces engaged in battle against the Trojans. The myth of Danaus, who is said to have originated from Egypt, serves as a foundational legend for the city of Argos. According to myth, his daughters, the Danaides, were condemned to pour water from a jug into a bottomless bathtub in Tartarus, a task that is perpetually unfulfilled. This myth shares a kinship with the legend of Sisyphus, another fabled task that is doomed to remain unfinished. The name "Danaan" may be derived from the Proto-Indo-European root "*danu-", which means "river". Despite extensive scholarly inquiry, no universally accepted theory has emerged to explain the origins of the Danaans. Some researchers have posited a connection between the Danaans and the Denyen, a group of sea peoples who launched a campaign against Egypt during the reign of Pharaoh Ramesses III (1187-1156 BCE). The same inscription also references the Weshesh, who may have been the ancestors of the Achaeans. The Denyen appear to have inhabited the city of Adana in Cilicia. Notably, pottery styles reminiscent of the Danaans have been discovered in the region.

In 1969, Arnold Schwarzenegger's life took a significant turn when he met Barbara Outland, an English teacher, with whom he lived until 1974. In his 1977 memoir, Schwarzenegger candidly reflected on his relationship with Barbara, stating: "Ultimately, it came down to our vastly different outlooks on life. She sought a straightforward, stable existence, whereas I was a free-spirited individual who detested the idea of a mundane life." Barbara Baker, as she later became known, described Schwarzenegger as "a jovial personality, incredibly charming, adventurous, and athletic" in her early interactions with him. However, she claimed that as their relationship progressed, he became "intolerable – classic narcissism – the world revolved around him." Baker published her memoir, "Arnold and Me: In the Shadow of the Austrian Oak," in 2006, which featured a foreword by Schwarzenegger himself. Although the book presented a sometimes unflattering portrayal of their relationship, Schwarzenegger chose to contribute to the publication and even met with Baker for three hours. Baker revealed in her memoir that she only discovered Schwarzenegger's infidelity after they parted ways, and she described their relationship as tumultuous.

The environment in which adolescents grow up significantly influences their identity formation. Research has predominantly focused on white, middle-class youth, revealing that those from more affluent backgrounds tend to develop their identities more effectively. This period of identity formation is a pivotal stage in an individual's life, and recent studies indicate that the transition to adulthood is now taking place over a longer period than previously observed. As a result, the youth stage, encompassing late adolescence and early adulthood, has gained prominence in the life course. This shift has underscored the importance of various factors in shaping an adolescent's social identity, including commitment, coping mechanisms, and social media. Notably, all these factors are influenced by the environment in which an adolescent grows up. Children from more privileged backgrounds, for instance, are exposed to more opportunities and better circumstances, which can have a lasting impact on their identity development.

Thuringia's landscapes showcase remarkable diversity. The northernmost part of the region is characterized by the Harz mountains, giving way to the Golden Valley, a lush and fertile floodplain surrounding Nordhausen, where the Helme River plays a significant role. The northwestern sector is comprised of the Eichsfeld, a hilly and partially forested region that is the source of the Leine River. The central and northern areas of Thuringia are dominated by the 3,000-square-kilometer Thuringian Basin, a highly fertile and flat region centered around the Unstrut River, which is entirely surrounded by a series of hill chains (listed in a counterclockwise direction from the northwest): Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge, and Hainich. Within the Basin, smaller hill chains include Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen. South of the Thuringian Basin lies the region's largest mountain range, marked by the Thuringian Forest to the northwest, the Thuringian Highlands in the middle, and the Franconian Mountains in the south.

The social connections that adolescents forge with their peers, family, and surrounding social circle hold immense significance in their overall social development. As adolescents navigate the nuances of friendship and acquaintanceship, they often become deeply emotionally invested in their relationships. While this emotional investment is not inherently problematic, it can become an issue if friends introduce them to harmful situations, thereby exemplifying the concept of peer pressure. During adolescence, individuals are particularly susceptible to the influence of those they form close bonds with, making this period a critical juncture in their social development. As they begin to exercise greater autonomy in making their own decisions, relationships take on added importance, as they help adolescents comprehend the intricacies of social dynamics. The profound impact of peer relationships during this formative period underscores the vital role they play in shaping an adolescent's social development.

In June 2013, Kanye West and celebrity Kim Kardashian welcomed their first child, North, to the world. Later that year, in October, the couple announced their engagement to widespread media attention. West then started working on his next studio album in November 2013, aiming to release it by mid-2014, with renowned producers Rick Rubin and Q-Tip. In the same month, Adidas announced a new partnership with West, with the debut collection set to premiere the following year. In May 2014, West and Kardashian exchanged vows in a private ceremony in Florence, Italy, with a star-studded guest list. West released the single "Only One" featuring Paul McCartney on December 31, 2014, and followed it up with "FourFiveSeconds" in January 2015, a collaborative effort with Rihanna and McCartney. Additionally, West appeared on the Saturday Night Live 40th Anniversary Special, premiering a new song titled "Wolves" featuring Sia Furler.

Many contemporary rock musicians incorporate mandolins into their music, often opting for single-stringed electric models over traditional double-stringed acoustic mandolins. A notable example is Tim Brennan, the guitarist of the Irish-American punk rock band Dropkick Murphys, who, along with his bandmates, incorporates Celtic instruments like the mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes into their sound. According to the band, these instruments help achieve the distinctive growling tone they aim for. Notably, the 1991 hit single "Losing My Religion" by R.E.M. was driven by guitarist Peter Buck's simple yet effective mandolin riffs, which also appeared in nearly a dozen other songs. Similarly, Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes frequently employs the mandolin, with a notable example being his use of the instrument.

Predators and prey often exist in a cyclical relationship, where one organism serves as food for another. Blue jays, for instance, prey on insects, but they themselves may become prey for cats, snakes, or hawks. A more nuanced way to categorize predators is by their trophic level. Organisms that consume autotrophs, or producers, are referred to as herbivores or primary consumers, while those that feed on heterotrophs, such as animals, are classified as secondary consumers, a type of carnivore. However, there are also tertiary consumers that feed on these carnivores, followed by quartary consumers that consume them, and so on. Due to the limited energy transfer between trophic levels, this hierarchy of predation must eventually terminate, typically within five or six levels, although it may only reach three levels in some cases. For example, a lion that preys upon large herbivores like wildebeest illustrates this concept.

In 680, Ibn al-Zubayr fled Medina and sought refuge in Mecca, while Husayn became aware of the people of Kufa's desire for him to take over, promising their full support. To gauge their sincerity, Husayn dispatched his cousin Muslim bin Agail to verify the situation. Upon learning of this development, Yazid I dispatched Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad, the ruler of Basrah, with explicit instructions to thwart the people of Kufa's plans to rally behind Husayn. Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad succeeded in dispersing the crowd gathered around Muslim bin Agail, capturing him in the process. As Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad's true intentions became clear – to prevent Husayn from gaining support in Kufa – Muslim bin Agail requested that a message be sent to Husayn, urging him to abandon his plans to migrate to Kufa. However, Husayn's supporters refused to heed this warning, and Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad continued to exert his influence in the region.

On September 1, 1870, the Battle of Sedan commenced as the Army of Châlons, consisting of 202 infantry battalions, 80 cavalry squadrons, and 564 guns, clashed with the combined Prussian Third and Meuse Armies, which fielded 222 infantry battalions, 186 cavalry squadrons, and 774 guns. General De Wimpffen, commander of the French V Corps in reserve, aimed to launch a joint infantry and cavalry assault against the Prussian XI Corps. However, by 11:00, Prussian artillery took a devastating toll on the French forces, while additional Prussian troops poured onto the battlefield. The French cavalry, led by General Marguerite, launched three daring charges against the Prussian XI Corps, which was concentrated in the nearby village of Floing. Marguerite was fatally wounded during the initial charge, and the subsequent attacks resulted in significant losses without yielding any significant gains. By day's end, with all hope of breaking through the Prussian lines exhausted, the French forces were left reeling.
